Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Composite Surfacing of Amorphous Materials by Laser Interference Nanopatterning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative research grant is the development of a novel laser-based surface engineering technique to enhance the ductility of non-crystalline materials, primarily metals. Laser interference patterning will be employed to produce modified regions of periodic lines or dots of localized ultrafine grain structure with residual stresses on the surface of these materials. The major objectives of the research are (i) to identify the thermo-physical effects associated with the interaction of modulated laser intensity during interference patterning and (ii) to characterize the modulated microstructure, crystallization dynamics, and distribution of residual stresses during laser patterning. These objectives will be instrumental in establishing the role of surface modification on enhancing global plasticity of the non-crystalline materials. Finally, a computational model based on the thermo-physical interactions associated with laser interference patterning of non-crystalline material surfaces for tailoring the effects will be developed.

Successful completion of this project on laser interference patterning will significantly advance the state-of-the-art in ductilization of inherently brittle non-crystalline alloys leading to wider acceptance of these materials for advanced structural applications. The research will elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of plasticity enhancement of non-crystalline materials through design of periodic surface structures consisting of original non-crystalline regions and regions of ultrafine grain structure with residual stresses. Through synergistic computational and experimental approach, the research is expected to establish a methodology for design and synthesis of next generation structural materials system. Furthermore, the collaborative project will provide opportunities for students to work on novel and advanced processing methods and materials and will help prepare diverse and capable workforce of next generation global scientists/engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amorphous alloys or bulk metallic glasses are advanced materials with disordered atomic arrangements. Compared to the conventional polycrystalline materials, the amorphous alloys exhibit superior properties such as strength, elastic limit, and corrosion resistance. However, the utilization of amorphous alloys in practical applications is limited due to their brittleness and insufficient surface mechanical properties. Laser surface processing is a flexible technique for the modification surface microstructures and properties of a range of materials. The major objective of this project was to investigate the effects of localized laser irradiation on the surface microstructure and properties of the amorphous alloys. The project involved laser surface processing of amorphous alloys with a range of processing parameters and the characterization of developed microstructure and properties in the laser irradiated amorphous alloys. The project demonstrated that the localized (site-specific) laser heating of the amorphous alloys produces several effects such as structural relaxation (local atomic ordering), nanocrystallization (composite surfacing), and surface deformations (out-of-plane buckling) of the amorphous alloys. The effects such as structural relaxation and nanocrystallization cause hardening of the surfaces, resulting in improved microhardness and wear resistance of the amorphous alloys. Detailed investigations on the effect of laser processing parameters on the microstructure and mechanical properties were performed to establish the regimes of laser processing parameters for these effects. These surface hardening effects are likely to be useful for developing the amorphous alloys for tribological applications. The deformation/buckling of the laser irradiated amorphous alloys was primarily due to thermal effects (temperature distribution and gradient) in the thickness direction of thin amorphous ribbons. Such deformations of the thin ribbons of amorphous alloys are likely to be useful in shaping and forming of the amorphous alloy sheets into useful shapes. Finite element models of the thermal effects of laser surface processing of amorphous alloys were developed to predict the temperatures, thermal gradients, heating/cooling rates in the amorphous alloys. The results of finite element models supported the observations of structural relaxations and nanocrystallization of the amorphous alloys upon laser irradiation. The results of this project have been presented in several journal publications and conference presentations. The project provided research opportunities to several graduate and undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented minorities. These experiences are likely to encourage the students to pursue further educational and career opportunities in the science and technology disciplines.
